awd_titl_txt: Materials World Network, SusChEM: Control of Interfacial Chemistry in Reactive Nanolaminates (CIREN)
awd_abstract_narration:
Technical Summary
This US/France collaborative project funded by the Division of Materials Research will focus on fundamental studies of a novel class of sustainable reactive composite nanolaminates containing a metal (commonly aluminum) and metal oxide (commonly copper oxide, iron(III) oxide, and zinc oxide).  The materials attracted great interest in the energetic material community since they are characterized by a high energy and power density (superior to supercapacitors), and are low cost and safe, useful for micro-thermal sources, micro-actuators and enablers for environmentally clean primers, miniature safe detonators, in-situ welding and soldering, and also chemical neutralization agents.  Yet, interfaces play a critical role during the synthesis and the utilization of these reactive layered nanostructures. The formation of interfacial layers is not only poorly understood but uncontrolled at present. A fundamental understanding of the formation and role of these aluminum/metal-oxide interfacial layers would not only bring control of such systems, but also be transformative for fundamental and practical advances in this field. This project aims at developing an atomic-level understanding of the interface formation process between Aluminum/Metal-oxide by combining in-situ spectroscopy and imaging with Density Functional Theory calculations for a variety of deposition methods. To this end, model surfaces and atomically precise deposition methods (e.g. atomic layer deposition) will be used to derive detailed atomic information, in combination with nanopatterning processes to quantify the contribution of the interfacial layers for both the reaction kinetics and the stability at low temperatures. Deposition/synthesis issues specifically associated with highly reactive materials are unraveled by the development of novel theoretical methods coupled with extensive and unique in situ characterization methods.  Thermal characterization techniques combustion tests combined with high resolution imaging and x-ray diffraction will be used to quantitatively evaluate the role of such interfaces in operating conditions. This project constitutes a first step in understanding the role of interfaces in reactive hetero-structures. 
Aluminum, copper, iron and zinc are all widely available and recyclable resources and common materials in microelectronics. These Aluminum/metal oxide nanolaminates are therefore sustainable, totally safe and not toxic for the environment and human health, requiring no hazardous substances and releasing no pollutant chemicals for their productions. The social, environmental and economic benefits are clear since these nanomaterials and nanostructures will contribute to reducing the use of many dangerous and polluting energetic materials (containing lead salt for example or synthesized using polluting chemistry). 

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
Reactive materials are critical for defense and energy. Ultra-thin layers of reactive materials, called reactive composite nanolaminates (e.g. aluminum and copper oxide), have attracted great interest in the energetic material community since they are characterized by a high energy and power density and are low cost and safe, useful for miniature thermal sources, actuators, detonators, and chemical neutralization agents. Most investigations have focused on the relationship between the structure and thermal properties of these reactive and metastable nanolaminates. Yet, interfaces play a critical role during their synthesis and utilization. The nature of interfaces is not only poorly understood but uncontrolled at present. A fundamental understanding of the formation and role of these interfacial layers would not only bring control of such systems, but also be transformative for fundamental and practical advances in energy and defense fields.  By combining growth, characterization and theoretical studies, this project provides the foundation towards the design of future tailored reactive nanostructures by interface optimization using atomically precise technologies. It establishes a bridge between the fields of reactive materials and solid state and material chemistry. It provides a multidisciplinary environment for the students, besides the benefits of cultural exchange. There is a focused integration of the research topic into educational programs (graduate courses, tutorials, certificates) both in the US and in France. At UT Dallas, this project engages underrepresented minority and women graduate students, and is a backbone for targeted outreach within the greater Dallas area. It supports existing programs developed by the UT Dallas Office of Diversity and Community Engagement, and programs to mentor and engage undergraduates in research such as the Academic Bridge and the Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation programs.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Detonators are used in a wide range of applications, such in the automobile or aeronautic industries (e.g. to release air bags or ejectable seats), for fireworks, and in the defense industry. They are composed of explosive mixtures of highly reactive materials, called thermites. Such mixtures are intrinsically dangerous and bulky, with limited shelf life. There has therefore been a strong effort by materials scientists to develop microsystems by combining reactive materials on the nanoscale, which could achieve the same goals, yet be intrinsically safe to handle with long shelf life. They have established that such reactive nanocomposites (e.g. nanolaminates, ultra-thin layers of reactive materials) are characterized by much higher energy and power density than supercapacitors, yet low cost, safe and with expanded applications. For instance, they can be used for welding and soldering at the microscale or for killing cancer cells, and also as chemical neutralization agents.

Most investigations of these reactive nanoscale nanostructures have focused on the relationship between the structure (i.e. arrangement of these materials) and the resulting thermal properties. However, interfaces play a critical role during the fabrication and the utilization of these reactive layered nanostructures because the two materials can spontaneously react to form an unwanted interfacial layer, which decreases the efficiency. The formation of interfacial layers was not only poorly understood but uncontrolled when our work started. We therefore focused on developing a fundamental understanding of the formation and properties of these metal/metal oxide interfacial layers not only to bring control of such systems, but also to provide a platform for novel applications.

Our work has focused on the most energetic system made of aluminum (Al) and copper oxide (CuO) because it can produce the most energy and is the most studied system. Our first contribution was to show that the interface between Al and CuO could be completely stabilized by depositing an ultra-thin layer of aluminum oxide, literally 2 to 3 atomic layer thick, using a novel technique called atomic layer deposition. With that ultra-thin layer on CuO, further deposition of Al did not penetrate into CuO to form an unwanted interfacial layer. This technique has direct impact on the industrial development of the nanothermites.

The next contribution was the discovery that a thin Cu layer (~ 5nm thick) deposited on Al would not only stabilize the interface but also enhance the release of energy later on when needed. The reason for this latter property is not trivial at all. It is based on the penetration of Cu into Al to form small alloy domains that act as trigger to initiate the energy release process. Alternatively, we demonstrated that the deposition an ultra-thin zinc oxide (ZnO) layer (~8 nm thick) on the CuO prior to Al deposition substantially stabilizes the CuO/Al interface and enhances the efficiency of the nanolaminate overall reaction (heat generated). With this layer, the CuO/ZnO/Al nanolaminates generates 98 % of the possible energy, compared to only 74% for the conventional CuO/Al nanolaminates, which is a substantial improvement for industrial applications.

The above findings were only possible with the implementation of novel and state-of-the-art experimental techniques for both the deposition and the characterization of the films, and the development of new theoretical methods to deal with energetic materials, that is systems in which the reactions are extremely fast and release enormous amounts of energy. In such cases, classical methods to explore the reaction and motion (diffusion) of elements break down, forcing us to develop new approaches. These new models and the understanding derived from the combined experimental characterization, performed at the University of Texas at Dallas (USA), and the theoretical models and calculations, performed at the LAAS-CNRS in Toulouse (France), will be important to develop a mechanistic understanding necessary for the rapid development of applications in this field.

In the course of these studies, several students from France visited UT Dallas, leading to two PhD theses in Toulouse. These students benefited from the extensive characterization facilities and expertise of the UT Dallas team. Two students from UT Dallas were involved in the project. One left with a Masters to work in industry. The other one, Yuzhi Gao, spent six months in France in 2017 with the support of a Chateaubriand fellowship bestowed by the French government to learn the modeling techniques necessary to interpret her data. She is finishing a dual degree (from UT Dallas and the University Paul Sabatier in Toulouse) and will defend her thesis in March 2018. The PI also supported and contributed to an outreach program “Young Women in Science and Engineering Investigators”, created in 2012, that provides a year-long research experience with a circle of four mentors (graduate student, professor, industry, and teacher) to teams of high school girls (primarily Hispanic and African American) from low socio-economic backgrounds.

 


Last Modified: 11/11/2017
Modified by: Yves J Chabal
